sections.summary: The surah affirms the **truth** of the Scripture and points to celestial and terrestrial phenomena—such as the heavens raised without pillars and the irrigation of diverse fruits—as proofs of **Divine Sovereignty** [186–187].

It addresses skepticism regarding **resurrection** and the demands for physical miracles, warning that those who defy their Lord will be shackled in the **Fire** despite the clear historical examples of past generations.

Allah is described as the Knower of the **Unseen** and the contents of the womb, maintaining protecting **guards** over every soul. Natural elements like lightning and **thunder** are portrayed as agents of both fear and hope that actively glorify the Creator [187–188].

sections.theme: The Parable of Truth and Falsehood
sections.summary: A contrast is drawn between the Creator and helpless protectors through the analogy of water and froth. It establishes that while **falsehood** eventually vanishes like foam, that which benefits humanity remains as the **truth**.

sections.theme: Attributes of the Righteous and Losers
sections.summary: Success is promised to those who fulfill their **covenant**, maintain kinship, and endure with **patience**. Conversely, those who violate their pledge and spread **corruption** on earth are cursed and destined for a miserable home [188–189].

sections.theme: The Power of Remembrance and Revelation
sections.summary: True guidance and **tranquility** of the heart are found in the **remembrance of Allah**. The text emphasizes that all decisions rest with Allah, even if a **revelation** were powerful enough to move mountains or revive the dead.

sections.theme: Historical Lessons and the Arabic Code
sections.summary: Disbelievers are reminded of the fate of those who ridiculed past messengers and are warned of **retribution** in both lives. The Quran is presented as an **Arabic code of law**, demanding total devotion to Allah and rejection of vain desires.

This concluding range notes that every messenger was given a **scripture** appropriate for their era and that Allah affirms or abolishes what He wills. It asserts Allah as the ultimate **Judge** and sufficient witness against those who deny the messenger’s mandate [190–191].
